description: Move or rename files and directories.
caveats: Does not work across filesystems for directories; use rsync for large moves.
Be careful: deleted files cannot be easily recovered.

description: Remove directories and their contents recursively.

recommended_flags.description: Copy only when the SOURCE file is newer than the destination file or when the destination file is missing

caveats: For large or remote copies, use rsync.

description: Efficiently synchronize files and directories between locations.

recommended_flags.description: Compress file data during the transfer
Delete extraneous files from destination dirs

caveats: Be careful with --delete; it will remove files in the destination not present in the source.

use_case: Archive or compress files and directories
description: Create compressed or uncompressed archive files (tarballs).
caveats: The order of flags matters; -f should be last before the archive name.

description: Extract files from tar, tar.gz, tar.bz2, or tar.xz archives.
caveats: The order of flags matters; -f should be last before the archive name.

recommended_flags.description: Encrypt the archive with a password

caveats: Not all systems have zip installed by default.

description: Extract files from zip archive files.
caveats: Not all systems have unzip installed by default.

description: Change the owner and/or group of files and directories.

recommended_flags.description: Operate on files and directories recursively
Report only when a change is made

caveats: Requires superuser privileges to change ownership to another user. Use with caution, especially recursively.

description: Search for files and directories in a directory hierarchy based on name, type, size, modification time, and other criteria.

recommended_flags.description: Filter by file type (f=file, d=directory, l=symlink, etc.)
Execute a command on each found item

caveats: Can be slow on large directory trees. Quoting patterns is important to avoid shell expansion. Use -exec with care.

description: Print system information such as the kernel name, network node hostname, kernel release, and more.
caveats: The information shown depends on the system and available kernel features. For detailed OS info, use lsb_release or /etc/os-release.

description: Install GUI applications (casks) using Homebrew. Note: 'brew cask' command is deprecated, use 'brew install --cask' instead.

recommended_flags.description: Install a cask (GUI application) instead of a formula
Force installation even if already installed
Skip macOS quarantine for downloaded applications

caveats: The 'brew cask' command was deprecated in Homebrew 2.6.0. Always use 'brew install --cask' instead of 'brew cask install'. Casks install GUI applications to /Applications by default.

use_case: List installed GUI applications with Homebrew
description: List all installed GUI applications (casks) installed via Homebrew.
caveats: The 'brew cask list' command was deprecated. Use 'brew list --cask' instead.

use_case: Search for GUI applications in Homebrew
description: Search for available GUI applications (casks) in Homebrew repositories.
caveats: The 'brew cask search' command was deprecated. Use 'brew search --cask' instead.

description: Add, list, or remove Homebrew tap repositories. Taps are additional repositories that provide formulas and casks.
caveats: Taps are stored in /usr/local/Homebrew/Library/Taps (Intel) or /opt/homebrew/Library/Taps (Apple Silicon). Common taps include homebrew/core (default), homebrew/cask (default), and homebrew/cask-versions (for older versions).

description: Remove Homebrew tap repositories that are no longer needed.

recommended_flags.description: Force removal even if formulas are installed

caveats: Be careful when removing taps as it may break installed formulas. Use 'brew list' to check what's installed from a tap before removing it.

description: Add the cask-versions tap to access older versions of applications.
caveats: The cask-versions tap provides older versions of applications. Use with caution as older versions may have security vulnerabilities. Format is typically 'application@version'.
